channel.title: Help Compiling Multiple Directories?
channel.description:
Does anyone know how to refer to multiple directories whilst compiling? I've looked at java docs, and all I could find was this:
Specifying a User Class Path Having changed one of the source files in the previous example, we recompile it: C:> cd \examples C:> javac greetings\Hi.java Since greetings.Hi refers to other classes in the greetings package, the compiler needs to find these other classes. The example above works, because our default user class path happens to be the directory containing the package directory. But suppose we want to recompile this file and not worry about which directory we're in? Then we need to add \examples to the user class path. We can do this by setting CLASSPATH, but here we'll use the -classpath option. C:>javac -classpath \examples \examples\greetings\Hi.java If we change greetings.Hi again, to use a banner utility, that utility also needs to be accessible through the user class path. C:>javac -classpath \examples;\lib\Banners.jar \ \examples\greetings\Hi.java To execute a class in greetings, we need access both to greetings and to the classes it uses. C:>java -classpath \examples;\lib\Banners.jar greetings.Hi
I've tried that, and apparently I'm doing it wrong. Either that, or that's not what I'm supposed to be doing. The files refer to each other in different directories and won't compile successfully unless the examples are specified. Errors come up with invalid referrals, methods don't exist, etc.

item.title: Help Compiling Multiple Directories?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

maybe I’m comprehending the question incorrectly…

wouldn’t the op have his source directories located in one main directory?

and, even if there were non-source directories, the batch would exclude those because they do not have source files.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Compiling Multiple Directories?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

or, you could use the for loop:

cd bin
for /r %%f in (*.java) do javac "%%f"

the above code will compile all java files, including the ones located in sub directories.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Compiling Multiple Directories?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:3, topic:310025”]Ripped:

@echo off title Compiler cd ../src echo Compiling iClarity.rs2 "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/*.java echo Compiling iClarity.rs2.io.packets "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/io/packets/*.java echo Compiling iClarity.rs2.npcs "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/npcs/*.java echo Compiling iClarity.rs2.players "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/players/*.java echo Compiling iClarity.rs2.util "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/util/*.java echo Compiling iClarity.rs2.world "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin\javac.exe" -cp . -d ../bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/world/*.java echo Compiling completed. pause [/quote]

That entire thing can be simplified immensely:

javac -cp . -d …/bin/ ./iClarity/rs2/.java ./iClarity/rs2//.java ./iClarity/rs2///.java

But honestly, you would be better off using ant.

As to the thread starter, just specify all of the files on the command line like the command above.

Read full topic

item.title: Help Compiling Multiple Directories?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

Does anyone know how to refer to multiple directories whilst compiling? I’ve looked at java docs, and all I could find was this:

Specifying a User Class Path

Having changed one of the source files in the previous example, we recompile it:
C:> cd
\examples
C:> javac greetings\Hi.java
Since greetings.Hi refers to other classes in the greetings package, the compiler needs to find these other classes. The example above works, because our default user class path happens to be the directory containing the package directory. But suppose we want to recompile this file and not worry about which directory we’re in? Then we need to add \examples to the user class path. We can do this by setting CLASSPATH, but here we’ll use the -classpath option.
C:>javac -classpath \examples \examples\greetings\Hi.java
If we change greetings.Hi again, to use a banner utility, that utility also needs to be accessible through the user class path.
C:>javac -classpath \examples;\lib\Banners.jar
\examples\greetings\Hi.java
To execute a class in greetings, we need access both to greetings and to the classes it uses.
C:>java -classpath \examples;\lib\Banners.jar greetings.Hi

I’ve tried that, and apparently I’m doing it wrong. Either that, or that’s not what I’m supposed to be doing.

The files refer to each other in different directories and won’t compile successfully unless the examples are specified. Errors come up with invalid referrals, methods don’t exist, etc.

Read full topic
